object.course_desc: Introduction to issues and methods in the study of music. Development of writing and research skills; methodological approaches in all academic areas of music (historical musicology, ethnomusicology, popular music studies, music theory).
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): first-year enrolment in the B.Mus., B.A. Music or B.A. Hons. Music program.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: first-year enrolment in the B.Mus., B.A. Music or B.A. Hons. Music program.

object.course_desc: Western classical music from the medieval period to the present. Major historical periods (Medieval, Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, Modern, Postmodern) are examined through representative music ranging from Gregorian chant to contemporary experimental trends.
object.course_extra_details: Lectures three hours a week.

object.course_desc: History of world popular music from the 19th century until the present. Topics may include the growth of the music industry, the impact of technology, stardom, world music, the role of the press, copyright, censorship, and sexuality.
object.course_extra_details: Lectures three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Through musical examples drawn from diverse cultures and historical periods, students develop the ability to describe and analyze different aspects of music and deepen their appreciation of music as a cultural experience. No credit for students in B.Mus, B.A. Honours Music or B.A. Music.
object.course_extra_details: Lectures three hours a week.

object.course_desc: An introduction to the rudiments of music and aural training. Successful completion of this course will fulfil the prerequisite for entry into MUSI 1700. Not available to B.Mus. students for credit.
object.course_extra_details: Lectures three hours a week.

object.course_desc: An introduction to the organizational principles underlying tonal music including intervals, scales, rhythm, metre, chords, counterpoint, form, cadences, and harmonic progressions.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the Discipline.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: A study of the harmonic, melodic, rhythmic and formal structures of music of the common-practice period, with emphasis on the development of analytical and written skills of diatonic music.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1700 or permission of the Discipline.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1700 or permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: A study of ear training, sight singing, and basic keyboard skills in relation to classical and popular musics, with emphasis on melodic, harmonic, and formal structures.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): permission of the Discipline.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: A study of the rhythm of selected classical, popular, and world musics, with emphasis on applied performance, movement, and dictation.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): permission of the Discipline.
Lectures and workshops three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: Individual vocal or instrumental instruction in classical, traditional or popular idioms, in addition to individual performances and group class instruction.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): audition and enrolment in the B.Mus. program; first-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
object.course_prerequisites: audition and enrolment in the B.Mus. program; first-year standing or permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: Individual vocal or instrumental instruction in classical, traditional or popular idioms, in addition to individual performances and group class instruction.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1900 and enrolment in the B.Mus. program; first-year standing or permission of the Discipline.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1900 and enrolment in the B.Mus. program; first-year standing or permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: Participation in a choral ensemble, by arrangement with the Supervisor of Performance and Practical Studies. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week throughout either the fall or winter term and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 1912. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week throughout either the fall or winter term and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.

object.course_desc: Participation in an instrumental ensemble, by arrangement with the Supervisor of Performance and Practical Studies. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week throughout either the fall or winter term and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 1914. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week throughout either the fall or winter term and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: first-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.

object.course_desc: A survey of ragtime and jazz from their roots in pre-twentieth-century black music and white music to contemporary jazz idioms, including an examination of New Orleans jazz and Dixieland, swing, bebop, cool jazz, and free jazz.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2205.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Selected aspects of the development of Anglo-American popular musics from their roots in the nineteenth century until the shifts and tensions which led to the advent of rock-and-roll and soul in the 1950s. Genres to be examined include blues, country, the sentimental ballad, Broadway music.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2203, MUSI 2206, MUSI 2208.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Selected aspects of the development of Anglo-American and world popular musics from the advent of rock `n' roll and soul to the present. Early rock `n' roll, British rhythm `n' blues, Motown, West Coast music, punk, heavy metal, new wave, disco and country.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2207, MUSI 2208, MUSI 2209.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: A survey of musical traditions from various regions of the world, with an emphasis on the sociocultural contexts in which those musics are created and performed.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2300.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: A comparative and analytical study of music in Asia, including India, China, Korea, Indonesia, Japan, and the Arabic world, through an examination of the music, musical instruments and theoretical systems.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2301.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: The Baroque (1600-1750) was simultaneously shaped by absolutist regimes, competing religions, and an emerging public sphere. Music and culture from Monteverdi to Bach and Handel are investigated in the contexts of power, (geo)politics, religion, aesthetics, gender, socio-economics, dissemination, genre, and compositional practices.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2001.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Peace and revolution, faith and secularism, noble privilege and bourgeois commerce: fundamental contradictions underlying the creative work of Mozart, Haydn, and Beethoven. This course studies their compositions—operas, sacred works, symphonies, chamber music—within the political, social and cultural institutions of their times (ca. 1730-1815).
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2002.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Introduction to the fundamentals of effective and professional arranging. All aspects of the various instruments of the orchestra and matters having to do with the practicalities of orchestration for both small and large ensembles, and accepted professional standards of score presentation.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1701 and MUSI1710 and MUSI1711, or permission of the instructor.
Lecture three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1701 and MUSI1710 and MUSI1711, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Introduction to theories and technicalities involved in original creative writing through the preparation of individual assignments; based in the practice of recent music in the Western Classical tradition while allowing for the music of other Western styles and traditions to be addressed.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1701 and MUSI1710 and MUSI1711, or permission of the instructor. MUSI2601 is recommended.
Lectures and workshops three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1701 and MUSI1710 and MUSI1711, or permission of the instructor. MUSI2601 is recommended.

object.course_desc: Introduction to the special stylistic features of choral music from the Renaissance to the present as well as to a variety of practical techniques (vocal production, gesture, conducting patterns, diction, etc.).
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing in the B.Mus. program or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Introduction to the theory and practice of electronic music creation, focusing on audio editing, synthesis, sampling, beat-making, signal processing, and sound design, using a variety of professional-grade software packages.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2603 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week, plus individual studio time.
object.course_prerequisites: Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Computer-based music-making with an emphasis on collaborative approaches and performance-oriented tools and techniques. Introduces practices of remixing, live sound manipulation, preparation of original material for performance, and the use of hardware controllers in live performance and real-time musical collaboration using mobile technologies.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 2603 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week, plus individual studio time.
object.course_prerequisites: Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A continuation of the study of the harmonic, melodic, rhythmic and formal structures of music of the common-practice period and early twentieth century, with emphasis on chromaticism and the development of analytical and written skills.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1701 or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1701 or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A study of the rhythmic, melodic, harmonic and formal structures of popular musics.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1700 or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1700 or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A practical study of rhythm, harmony and melody on the keyboard, with an emphasis on vocal and instrumental accompaniment and the development of improvisation skills in a variety of styles.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1701 and MUSI1710 and MUSI1711, or permission of the instructor.
Labs three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1701 and MUSI1710 and MUSI1711, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A continuation of the study of ear training, sight singing, and basic keyboard skills in relation to classical and popular musics, with emphasis on melodic, harmonic, and formal structures.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1701, MUSI1710.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1701, MUSI1710.

object.course_desc: A continuation of the study of the rhythm of common-practice and world musics, with emphasis on applied performance, movement, and dictation.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): MUSI1700, MUSI1711.
Lectures and workshops three hours per week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI1700, MUSI1711.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 1901.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and MUSI1901 with a C+ or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and MUSI1901 with a C+ or higher, or permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 2900.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and MUSI2900 with a B- or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and MUSI2900 with a B- or higher, or permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 1913. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week throughout either the fall or winter term and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 2912. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week throughout either the fall or winter term and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 1915. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week through either the fall or winter term, and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 2914. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week throughout either the fall or winter term and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Ensemble Director.

object.course_desc: Through an examination of many genres and styles including classical, folk, popular, and jazz, this course explores the ways that music participates in shaping complex and often conflicting ideas about nation, place, and identity in Canada.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 3100 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: A survey of popular musics in Canada from early colonial times to the present.  The course will consider a wide range of musical styles and genres, along with related cultural and historical issues.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 3100.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Through a series of case studies, this course examines the impacts of globalization, colonialism and media in music-making and consumption of popular music practices found around the world.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: An introduction to the history and theory of classical Indian music including ragas, instruments, rhythm and improvisation.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: An examination of various musics, devotional traditions, and shifting cultural and art movements in the region, resulting from processes of globalization, political change, and technological innovation. Course sessions will include close and critical discussion of selected texts, audio-visual examples, and ethnomusicological documentary films.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Courses focusing on one selected aspect of music, in the area of musicology, theory or composition. The course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
Lectures and seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Courses focusing on one selected aspect of music, in the area of musicology, theory or composition. The course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
Lectures and seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Courses designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through courses in theory, musicology, or composition. Course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the department, and a minimum GPA of 9.0 in Music.
Individual instruction.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the department, and a minimum GPA of 9.0 in Music.

object.course_desc: Courses designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through performance. Course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the Department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.
Individual instruction.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the Department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.

object.course_desc: An examination of the integral role music plays in religion and sacred ritual in different world cultures and religions. Through various case studies, the course broadly considers how sacred soundscapes shape people’s worldviews, identities, and experiences within and outside of their communities.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as RELI3301.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: The role of gender in the theory and practice of music in western and non-western cultures.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Literature, practice and theory of music therapy. The use of music (improvisation, the voice, and reception) with various populations, including children and adults with special needs, people in long term care, people with neurological disorders, and in palliative care.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A survey of the development of opera from the beginnings to about 1800. The major monuments of Italian, French, German and English opera, by such composers as Monteverdi, Cavalli, Scarlatti, Purcell, Lully, Gluck, Rameau, Mozart and Haydn.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: A study of romantic and contemporary opera through an examination of selected works from Weber's Der Freischütz to Britten's Peter Grimes, including an investigation of national styles from Wagnerian music drama and Italian verismo to Russian realism and German expressionism.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: The use of music in film, from the silent era to the present day, studying the techniques, styles and theory of film music through the examination of selected scenes.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as FILM3402.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week, screening two hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: An introduction to the structure and history of the music industries.
object.course_extra_details:
Also listed as COMS3404.
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: A survey of the styles, works, and artists of the musical theatre genre as well as the artistic elements that comprise musical theatre.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Origins and development of orchestral music from its beginnings as an independent form in the 18th century to the present. Major symphonies and symphonic poems by composers like Haydn, Beethoven, Liszt, Brahms, Strauss, and Shostakovich. Brief examination of concerto and ballet music.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: History of chamber music and the cultural contexts within which it rose to prominence in Europe and North America in the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries. Genres by representative composers including the sonata, duos, trios, quartets, quintets, sextets, divertimenti, and works for small chamber orchestra.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: This course examines European art music of the nineteenth century, a revolutionary period of socio-political change when inspiration, subjectivity, radical idealism, expressive intensity, cultural nationalism, and the primacy of the individual creative voice were held up as primary aesthetic ideals.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): Third-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: Third-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A study of western art music of the 20th century. Musical works, compositional techniques and performance practices are examined in the context of musical innovation, social change, political upheaval, and stylistic pluralism in a rapidly changing “modern” world.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): Third-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: Third-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Designed to enable students to develop abilities in the writing of original music. The study and appreciation of modern and contemporary styles and techniques are encouraged.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 3600 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): MUSI2601, MUSI2602, and MUSI2700, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures, workshops, and individual consultations three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI2601, MUSI2602, and MUSI2700, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: An introduction to the techniques of sound synthesis primarily through practical experience at the digital synthesizer and computer. The basics of machine operations, software and computer applications to composition and synthesis. Enrolment is limited.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing and either MUSI2608 or MUSI2609, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week, plus individual studio time.
object.course_prerequisites: Enrolment in the BMus or BA Music program and second-year standing and either MUSI2608 or MUSI2609, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Examination of the various applications of digital equipment through the realization of original projects. Students may focus on studio composition, software development or analytic research. Appropriate compositional techniques and problem solving strategies are also discussed. Enrolment is limited.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing, and either MUSI 2603 (no longer offered) or MUSI2608 or MUSI2609, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures three hours a week, plus individual studio time.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing, and either MUSI 2603 (no longer offered) or MUSI2608 or MUSI2609, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Introduction to the practice of conducting Instrumental music from the Classical era to the present as well as to a variety of practical techniques (rehearsal techniques, gesture, conducting patterns, score study, etc.).
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing in the B.Mus. program or permission of the instructor.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing in the B.Mus. program or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Theoretical, practical and technical requirements of audio production in live settings are explored through lectures, demonstrations and workshops. Students develop skills in critical listening, pre-production planning, microphone selection and placement, signal routing, audio processing, monitoring and mixing for live event venues. Prior experience not required.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Lectures and workshops three hours a week.

object.course_desc: Selected topic in music theory. Topics will change yearly and may include: methods of music analysis, analysis of selected works, styles and structures of common practice or post common practice period, music,  modal, tonal, or post-tonal counterpoint, history of music theory.
object.course_extra_details:
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 3500.
Prerequisite(s): MUSI2700 or permission of the instructor.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI2700 or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Techniques of arranging and composition for small and large ensembles will be studied through the examination of selected works drawn from the jazz repertoire. Works will be selected for stylistic and theoretical analysis, for exercises in aural recognition, and for arranging purposes.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 4203 (taken in 1994-95) or MUSI 4204 (taken in 1995-96).
Prerequisite(s): MUSI2701 or permission of the instructor.
Workshops three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI2701 or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Basic topics in physics and psychoacoustics, with an emphasis on those concepts that are most useful for music performance, analysis, composition, and musicology.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): second-year standing.
Lectures three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: second-year standing.

object.course_desc: Selected forms of improvisation from diverse musical and cultural traditions.  In addition to weekly seminar meetings, the class will engage in experiential forms of learning by actively improvising in a weekly performance-oriented seminar.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing.
Discussion and performance seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 2901.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing in B. Mus. and MUSI2901 with a B- or higher, or permission of the Discipline.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing in B. Mus. and MUSI2901 with a B- or higher, or permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: This is an optional performance course for B.Mus. students with high academic standing.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 4900, MUSI 4901, MUSI 4907.
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI3901, A- or higher average in second- and third-year MUSI performance courses, and permission of the Music performance supervisor.
Individual instruction.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI3901, A- or higher average in second- and third-year MUSI performance courses, and permission of the Music performance supervisor.

object.course_desc: This is an optional performance course for B.Mus. students with high academic standing.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI4002, MUSI4003, MUSI 4900 (no longer offered), MUSI 4901, MUSI 4907.
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in B.Mus. standing, MUSI4000 with A- or higher, and permission of the Music performance supervisor.
Individual instruction.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in B.Mus. standing, MUSI4000 with A- or higher, and permission of the Music performance supervisor.

object.course_desc: A graduation recording of substantial duration arranged in consultation with the discipline. A proposal must be submitted one week before the last day for course changes. All recording costs must be borne by the student.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI4001, MUSI4003, MUSI 4900 (no longer offered), MUSI 4901 (no longer offered), MUSI 4907.
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI4000 with a grade of A- or higher, and permission of both the relevant associate music instructor and the music performance supervisor.
Individual instruction.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI4000 with a grade of A- or higher, and permission of both the relevant associate music instructor and the music performance supervisor.

object.course_desc: Public recital arranged in consultation with the Supervisor of Performance and Practical Studies. An outline of the program must be submitted one week before the last day for course changes.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI4001, MUSI4002, MUSI 4900, MUSI 4901, MUSI 4907.
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI4000 with A- or higher, and permission of both the relevant associate music instructor and the Music performance supervisor.
Individual instruction.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in B.Mus., MUSI4000 with A- or higher, and permission of both the relevant associate music instructor and the Music performance supervisor.

object.course_desc: An examination of key issues in the study of jazz including history/historiography, gender, genre, race, politics, identity and performance.
object.course_extra_details: Prerequisite(s): MUSI2005 and third-year standing.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI2005 and third-year standing.

object.course_desc: An introduction to current issues in the study of popular music. The course will be organized around a series of case studies.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing, MUSI1002, and at least one of MUSI2005, 2006, or 2007.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing, MUSI1002, and at least one of MUSI2005, 2006, or 2007.

object.course_desc: Examination of the life and music of a selected composer, and the historical, social, cultural, and political factors that shaped the context within which they worked. Focus on history, biography, musical style and analysis.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Lectures and seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: In this course students learn and apply research methods common to ethnomusicological research, developing an individual ethnographic project that draws on critical contemporary theories in ethnomusicology.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing, or permission of the instructor.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Critical analyses of diversity and multiculturalism narratives in Canada and the ways that settler-colonialism influenced and continues to inform music creation and expression. Various case studies examine the diversity of musics found in Canada and the ways that music facilitates belonging and/or exclusion to community.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as MUSI5015, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: This course examines the role of Indigenous music and musicians in various contemporary issues and priorities for First Peoples in Canada, including political activism, language and cultural maintenance and revitalization, environmental justice and the land, reconciliation and decolonization.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as MUSI5016, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: This course explores musics in Africa, engaging with issues of colonialism, ownership and copyright, politics and protest, social change, and global relationships.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third year standing, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures and seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third year standing, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Courses focusing on one selected aspect of music, in the area of either musicology, theory or composition. The course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
Lectures and seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Courses focusing on one selected aspect of music, in the area of either musicology, theory or composition. Course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
Lectures and seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Courses designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through courses in theory, musicology, or composition. Course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.
Individual instruction.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.

object.course_desc: Courses designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through performance. Course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): permission of the department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.
Individual instruction.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the department, and a minimum CGPA of 9.0 in Music.

object.course_desc: A course designed for Music Honours students who have acquired an extensive background through courses in theory, musicology or composition. Course offerings change from year to year.
object.course_extra_details: Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Examining music’s role in the multifaceted and complex processes of globalization. Drawing on case studies of “world musics”, this course explores how sound and music negotiate histories of post/colonialism, cultural and economic imperialism, and constructions of sameness and difference in “world music” contexts.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Also offered at the graduate level, with different requirements, as MUSI5017, for which additional credit is precluded.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: An examination of the ways in which music contributes to mental, social and physical wellbeing throughout the world, drawing from the fields of neuroscience, medical ethnomusicology, community music and cross-cultural studies.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: The music of the “dark ages” is illuminated in the context of politics, spectacle, devotion, celebration, compositional process, manuscript culture, dissemination, musical notation, plague, and courtly love. “Medievalism” is examined as an aesthetic of the era (ca. 400-1400) and as reinterpreted in our modern world.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: This course brings to life the Renaissance (1400-1600), when music played a vital role in lavish courts, grand cathedrals, and vibrant cities. Madrigals, masses, and motets are examined in the context of politics, religion, gender, manuscript and print culture, rhetoric, art, and architecture.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.
Seminar three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 3602, focusing on the development of creative individual approaches to music composition.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 3600 (no longer offered).
Prerequisite(s): MUSI3602, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures, workshops, and individual consultations three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI3602, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A study of a selected topic in music theory. Topics will change yearly and may include: methods of music analysis; analysis of selected works; styles and structures of common practice or post common practice period music; modal, tonal, or post-tonal counterpoint; history of music theory.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): MUSI2700 or permission of the instructor.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI2700 or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: The art of arranging for small and large jazz ensembles is introduced through analysis of recordings by artists such as Duke Ellington, Fletcher Henderson, Count Basie, Rob McConnell, and Maria Schneider. Topics may include 2-, 3-, and 4-voice writing in a jazz idiom.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): MUSI3701 or permission of the instructor.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI3701 or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Selected advanced topics in the perception and cognition of music.  Where appropriate, emphasis will be placed upon areas of overlap between psychological research and issues in aesthetics and cultural theory.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): third-year standing and MUSI3702, or permission of the department.
Seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: third-year standing and MUSI3702, or permission of the department.

object.course_desc: This course deals with the development of writing skills and knowledge of counterpoint as manifest in the Baroque era. Topics may include invention, canon, fugue, dance forms, the compositional language of J. S. Bach, and contrapuntal techniques in the late 18th century and beyond.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): MUSI2700, or permission of the instructor.
Lectures and seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI2700, or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Fundamentals of post-tonal music theory and analysis. Neo-tonal, atonal, twelve-tone and third-stream jazz.  Students will develop the critical skills to understand these theoretical tools and be conversant with some of the aesthetic precepts associated with them.
object.course_extra_details:
Prerequisite(s): MUSI2700 or permission of the instructor.
Lectures and seminars three hours a week.
object.course_prerequisites: MUSI2700 or permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: Practical experience in music-specific projects such as recording studios, librarianship, research, multimedia, etc. at local institutions. A maximum of one credit of practicum may be offered in fulfilment of Music requirements.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): Honours Music registration with third- or fourth-year standing and a B+ or better average in Music courses; and permission of the Practica Supervisor.
object.course_prerequisites: Honours Music registration with third- or fourth-year standing and a B+ or better average in Music courses; and permission of the Practica Supervisor.

object.course_desc: Practical experience in music-specific projects such as recording studios, librarianship, research, multimedia, etc. at local institutions. A maximum of one credit of practicum may be offered in fulfilment of Music requirements.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): Honours Music registration with third- or fourth-year standing and a B +  or better average in Music courses; and permission of the Practica Supervisor.
object.course_prerequisites: Honours Music registration with third- or fourth-year standing and a B +  or better average in Music courses; and permission of the Practica Supervisor.

object.course_desc: The course requires the composition of an original work of substantial proportions, with an accompanying analytical paper. Application to the Discipline for permission to register must be received by September 1.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Precludes additional credit for MUSI 4600.
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing, MUSI 3600 and permission of the Discipline.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing, MUSI 3600 and permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: An Honours research essay of approximately 50 pages. A written outline of the project must be submitted to the Honours committee changes by the first day of classes.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing, A- or higher average, and permission of the Discipline.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing, A- or higher average, and permission of the Discipline.

object.course_desc: The course requires the creation of an original work (or works) of substantial proportions using applications in the electronic studios. A high level of independence and originality will be required. Requests to the Discipline for permission to register must be received by September 1.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.
object.course_prerequisites: permission of the instructor.

object.course_desc: A continuation of MUSI 3913. Registration, but not participation, is restricted to students in the B.Mus. program. Graded Sat/Uns.
object.course_extra_details:
Includes: Experiential Learning Activity
Prerequisite(s): fourth-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
Ensemble work approximately two hours a week throughout either the fall or winter term and participation in concerts.
object.course_prerequisites: fourth-year standing in the B.Mus. program and permission of the Choral Director.
